abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews 1999 Muga white Rioja wine and notes its availability in New York City; photo (M)

block.p: The other day, La Caravelle, the three-star Manhattan restaurant, bought '99 Muga white Rioja to sell by the glass, a tipoff that the producer has fielded a winner.
Andre Jammet, an owner, finds that the wine goes with ''any fish, like salmon or cod; scallops or lobster; or any white meat -- veal, chicken, guinea hen.''

Andre Jammet, an owner, finds that the wine goes with ''any fish, like salmon or cod; scallops or lobster; or any white meat -- veal, chicken, guinea hen.''

Bodegas Muga, in the Rioja Alta region, is one of Spain's few traditionalists still rearing its wines wholly in oak. Indeed, an agreeably woody bouquet and flavor frame this barrel-fermented composition of native viura grapes with some malvasia.

Fans of barrel-fermented California chardonnay are likely to be wooed by the vanillan, almost baked-apple aroma with its hints of smoked meat, the ample body and creamy texture, the almost honeyed flavor, the roundness.

For optimum use, chill this bright, pale-brass-colored dry wine moderately and, in the casual manner of aficionados, keep swirling and sniffing it so that convection currents keep releasing its subtleties.

In Manhattan, the wine costs $11 at Martin Brothers, 2781 Broadway (107th Street); $12 (with a 20 percent case discount through Sept. 9 in a city where the maximum tends to be 15 percent) at Union Square Wine and Spirits, 33 Union Square West (East 17th Street); $11 at SoHo Wines, 461 West Broadway (Houston Street.
In Queens, the wine is $13 at Wine and Spirit Company, 108-50 Queens Boulevard (Continental Avenue), Forest Hills; in Brooklyn, it's $12 at Shawn, 141 Seventh Avenue (Carroll Street), Park Slope.

Muga is brokered by Jorge Ordo'nez, whose portfolio of Spanish estates sets high standards for quality. Merchants can obtain the wine from Tempranillo, an importer and distributor, in Mamaroneck, N.Y.
